Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Nurses' Roles in Smoking Cessation Interventions

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups

Participants.evidence: The study included patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) across various healthcare settings.

Intervention.evidence: Nurses employed motivational interviewing and the 5A method, distributing pamphlets and providing face-to-face education. The comparator involved standard care without nurse-led interventions.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was smoking cessation rates, measured over a six-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Smoking cessation rates improved significantly in the intervention group (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).
